BIOS207
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This course offers a comprehensive exploration of the fascinating world of animal behavior, delving into the mechanisms, functions, and ecological significance of behaviors exhibited by diverse species.

Throughout this module, students will engage with a variety of topics, including the ecological factors influencing behavior, social organization and communication, reproductive strategies, learning and cognition, and the practical applications of animal behavior research. Students will also study the interactions between an organism and its environment in an evolutionary context and how experiments have aided our understanding of animal behaviour. This module is taught using lectures, with some flipped classroom sessions for discussion. Assessment will be in the form of two pieces of written communication.
Educational Aims
(1) Introduce the fundamental evolutionary principles that explain a wide range of animal behaviours.

(2) Enable students to examine animal behaviour from a human perspective.

(3) Train students in the analysis and interpretation of behavioural data.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this module, students will explore the rich diversity of behaviours exhibited by various species, from the smallest insects to the largest mammals. Whether you're an aspiring biologist, or wildlife enthusiast, this module offers a comprehensive exploration of animal behavior that will inspire curiosity, critical thinking, and a deeper appreciation for the wonders of the natural world.

This module is taught using lectures, with some flipped classroom sessions for discussion. Through engaging lectures, interactive discussions, and in-depth study of scientific literature, students will gain insights into the evolutionary, ecological, and physiological factors that shape animal behavior. Through case studies and real-world examples, students will see how the principles of animal behaviour have practical applications across a variety of fields such as conservation, agriculture, and bioveterinary science. Assessment will be in the form of two pieces of written communication.
Outline Syllabus
Students will cover four main themes with examples of possible topics detailed below:

1) Fundamental Principles of Animal Behavior:
In this theme, students will cover topic areas that may include, but are not limited to ethology (the study of animal behaviour in natural environments); proximate vs ultimate explanations of behaviour; the role genetics play in behaviour; social behaviour and communication.

2) Animal Psychology:
In this theme students will cover topic areas that may include, but are not limited to learning and memory in animals; problem-solving and innovation; animal personality and individual differences and sensory perception and sensory ecology.

3) Experimental Design and Ethics:
In this theme students will cover topic areas that may include, but are not limited to the principles of experimental design in animal behavior research; ethical considerations in studying animal behavior; animal welfare regulations and guidelines and data collection methods: observation, surveys, and experiments.

4) Human Behavioral Ecology:
In this theme students will cover topic areas that may include, but are not limited to evolutionary perspectives on human behavior; cultural evolution and the transmission of behavior; cooperation and reciprocity in human societies and social learning and cultural variation.

Students will be provided with key learning resources available through Canvas and will be expected to complete independent reading in preparation for lectures.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching will come in the form of lectures and asynchronous recorded material. An average week will consist of 2 hours of lecture and 1 hour of asynchronous recorded material.


Teaching Method: Asynchronous recorded material

Description: Pre-lecture material (discussions)

This is an inclusive approach that allows students to prepare in advance for lectures. This increases confidence and allows time to reflect, anticipate difficulties and ask questions (asynchronously) before the session itself. Examples of preparatory material include recommended reading and short topic videos. Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards.


Teaching Method: Lecture

Description: Face-to-face lecture delivery

Students will attend face-to-face lectures for delivery of content to supplement that delivered asynchronously. In these sessions students will be able to ask questions about asynchronous content and consolidate knowledge through in-class group discussions. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.


Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment is via two written pieces of work. The first will be a written piece of coursework that will require some data analysis/interpretation and a project proposal. Data will be from published open-access sources, enhancing digital fluency in our students. This type of assessment enhances problem solving and critical thinking skills which are highly sought after by graduate employers, as well as being an example of authentic assessment for students.

The second assessment will be a second piece of written work, for example an essay or a blog, to enhance written and communication skills in students. Students will be given a choice of topic for this written piece which is a student-centred approach allowing students to pursue their area of interest and is therefore inclusive.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS207
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This course offers a comprehensive exploration of the fascinating world of animal behavior, delving into the mechanisms, functions, and ecological significance of behaviors exhibited by diverse species.

Throughout this module, students will engage with a variety of topics, including the ecological factors influencing behavior, social organization and communication, reproductive strategies, learning and cognition, and the practical applications of animal behavior research. Students will also study the interactions between an organism and its environment in an evolutionary context and how experiments have aided our understanding of animal behaviour. This module is taught using lectures, with some flipped classroom sessions for discussion. Assessment will be in the form of two pieces of written communication.
Educational Aims
(1) Introduce the fundamental evolutionary principles that explain a wide range of animal behaviours.

(2) Enable students to examine animal behaviour from a human perspective.

(3) Train students in the analysis and interpretation of behavioural data.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this module, students will explore the rich diversity of behaviours exhibited by various species, from the smallest insects to the largest mammals. Whether you're an aspiring biologist, or wildlife enthusiast, this module offers a comprehensive exploration of animal behavior that will inspire curiosity, critical thinking, and a deeper appreciation for the wonders of the natural world.

This module is taught using lectures, with some flipped classroom sessions for discussion. Through engaging lectures, interactive discussions, and in-depth study of scientific literature, students will gain insights into the evolutionary, ecological, and physiological factors that shape animal behavior. Through case studies and real-world examples, students will see how the principles of animal behaviour have practical applications across a variety of fields such as conservation, agriculture, and bioveterinary science. Assessment will be in the form of two pieces of written communication.
Outline Syllabus
Students will cover four main themes with examples of possible topics detailed below:

1) Fundamental Principles of Animal Behavior:
In this theme, students will cover topic areas that may include, but are not limited to ethology (the study of animal behaviour in natural environments); proximate vs ultimate explanations of behaviour; the role genetics play in behaviour; social behaviour and communication.

2) Animal Psychology:
In this theme students will cover topic areas that may include, but are not limited to learning and memory in animals; problem-solving and innovation; animal personality and individual differences and sensory perception and sensory ecology.

3) Experimental Design and Ethics:
In this theme students will cover topic areas that may include, but are not limited to the principles of experimental design in animal behavior research; ethical considerations in studying animal behavior; animal welfare regulations and guidelines and data collection methods: observation, surveys, and experiments.

4) Human Behavioral Ecology:
In this theme students will cover topic areas that may include, but are not limited to evolutionary perspectives on human behavior; cultural evolution and the transmission of behavior; cooperation and reciprocity in human societies and social learning and cultural variation.

Students will be provided with key learning resources available through Canvas and will be expected to complete independent reading in preparation for lectures.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching will come in the form of lectures and asynchronous recorded material. An average week will consist of 2 hours of lecture and 1 hour of asynchronous recorded material.


Teaching Method: Asynchronous recorded material

Description: Pre-lecture material (discussions)

This is an inclusive approach that allows students to prepare in advance for lectures. This increases confidence and allows time to reflect, anticipate difficulties and ask questions (asynchronously) before the session itself. Examples of preparatory material include recommended reading and short topic videos. Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards.


Teaching Method: Lecture

Description: Face-to-face lecture delivery

Students will attend face-to-face lectures for delivery of content to supplement that delivered asynchronously. In these sessions students will be able to ask questions about asynchronous content and consolidate knowledge through in-class group discussions. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.


Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment is via two written pieces of work. The first will be a written piece of coursework that will require some data analysis/interpretation and a project proposal. Data will be from published open-access sources, enhancing digital fluency in our students. This type of assessment enhances problem solving and critical thinking skills which are highly sought after by graduate employers, as well as being an example of authentic assessment for students.

The second assessment will be a second piece of written work, for example an essay or a blog, to enhance written and communication skills in students. Students will be given a choice of topic for this written piece which is a student-centred approach allowing students to pursue their area of interest and is therefore inclusive.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This course offers a comprehensive exploration of the fascinating world of animal behavior, delving into the mechanisms, functions, and ecological significance of behaviors exhibited by diverse species.

Throughout this module, students will engage with a variety of topics, including the ecological factors influencing behavior, social organization and communication, reproductive strategies, learning and cognition, and the practical applications of animal behavior research. Students will also study the interactions between an organism and its environment in an evolutionary context and how experiments have aided our understanding of animal behaviour. This module is taught using lectures, with some flipped classroom sessions for discussion. Assessment will be in the form of two pieces of written communication.
Educational Aims
(1) Introduce the fundamental evolutionary principles that explain a wide range of animal behaviours.

(2) Enable students to examine animal behaviour from a human perspective.

(3) Train students in the analysis and interpretation of behavioural data.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this module, students will explore the rich diversity of behaviours exhibited by various species, from the smallest insects to the largest mammals. Whether you're an aspiring biologist, or wildlife enthusiast, this module offers a comprehensive exploration of animal behavior that will inspire curiosity, critical thinking, and a deeper appreciation for the wonders of the natural world.

This module is taught using lectures, with some flipped classroom sessions for discussion. Through engaging lectures, interactive discussions, and in-depth study of scientific literature, students will gain insights into the evolutionary, ecological, and physiological factors that shape animal behavior. Through case studies and real-world examples, students will see how the principles of animal behaviour have practical applications across a variety of fields such as conservation, agriculture, and bioveterinary science. Assessment will be in the form of two pieces of written communication.
Outline Syllabus
Students will cover four main themes with examples of possible topics detailed below:

1) Fundamental Principles of Animal Behavior:
In this theme, students will cover topic areas that may include, but are not limited to ethology (the study of animal behaviour in natural environments); proximate vs ultimate explanations of behaviour; the role genetics play in behaviour; social behaviour and communication.

2) Animal Psychology:
In this theme students will cover topic areas that may include, but are not limited to learning and memory in animals; problem-solving and innovation; animal personality and individual differences and sensory perception and sensory ecology.

3) Experimental Design and Ethics:
In this theme students will cover topic areas that may include, but are not limited to the principles of experimental design in animal behavior research; ethical considerations in studying animal behavior; animal welfare regulations and guidelines and data collection methods: observation, surveys, and experiments.

4) Human Behavioral Ecology:
In this theme students will cover topic areas that may include, but are not limited to evolutionary perspectives on human behavior; cultural evolution and the transmission of behavior; cooperation and reciprocity in human societies and social learning and cultural variation.

Students will be provided with key learning resources available through Canvas and will be expected to complete independent reading in preparation for lectures.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching will come in the form of lectures and asynchronous recorded material. An average week will consist of 2 hours of lecture and 1 hour of asynchronous recorded material.


Teaching Method: Asynchronous recorded material

Description: Pre-lecture material (discussions)

This is an inclusive approach that allows students to prepare in advance for lectures. This increases confidence and allows time to reflect, anticipate difficulties and ask questions (asynchronously) before the session itself. Examples of preparatory material include recommended reading and short topic videos. Students will have access to materials online such as teaching materials and online discussion boards.


Teaching Method: Lecture

Description: Face-to-face lecture delivery

Students will attend face-to-face lectures for delivery of content to supplement that delivered asynchronously. In these sessions students will be able to ask questions about asynchronous content and consolidate knowledge through in-class group discussions. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.


Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment is via two written pieces of work. The first will be a written piece of coursework that will require some data analysis/interpretation and a project proposal. Data will be from published open-access sources, enhancing digital fluency in our students. This type of assessment enhances problem solving and critical thinking skills which are highly sought after by graduate employers, as well as being an example of authentic assessment for students.

The second assessment will be a second piece of written work, for example an essay or a blog, to enhance written and communication skills in students. Students will be given a choice of topic for this written piece which is a student-centred approach allowing students to pursue their area of interest and is therefore inclusive.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
